### Slightly improve your score with these two lines.
Say you read in the `train_features.csv` as `train`, and `test_features.csv` as `test`, *i.e.*
source.f73912c1: then before doing anything else directly insert these next two lines, which will set all of the `ctl_vehicle` values to 0. (of which there are 1866 in `train_features.csv`, and 358 in `test_features.csv`):
source.545a7943:
Why do this? Because these values represent what are known as *vehicle controls*:
> Vehicle controls refer to negative controls that should not cause significant changes in expression.

From [Connectopedia](https://clue.io/connectopedia/glossary):
> **Controls—Vehicles (VC)**:   Various forms of “inert” experiments performed to determine, by contrast, effects that are specifically due to a perturbation as opposed to responses associated with handling cells or delivering a perturbagen; a type of negative control.

I have found that setting these controls to 0 improved my score by **0.00012**. I know it is not much at the moment, but it may come in handy later...

Thanks are due to the Topic ["Don't put drugs into Vehicle Control"](https://www.kaggle.com/c/lish-moa/discussion/180165) by [Laevatein](https://www.kaggle.com/laevatein), as well as the comment by the competition organizer [mrbhbs](https://www.kaggle.com/mrbhbs):
> "*Yes. The "controls" are samples with no compounds (and hence no MoAs). In real applications, they can be used as a baseline to assess the effect of a compound treatment. Here, the best you can do is to set the probability of MoA to 0.*"

on the post [About "Controlled Perturbations"](https://www.kaggle.com/c/lish-moa/discussion/180304) by [Dorukhan Afacan](https://www.kaggle.com/afajohn).
